title: Agentic AI
text:
1 Syllabus
Welcome to the Agentic AI module of the Management Information Systems course!
In this part of the course, we will explore the world of Agentic Artificial Intelligence. Unlike traditional generaive AI that simply responds to prompts, Agentic AI systems can perceive their environment, reason about tasks, and take actions to achieve specific goals.

title: Agentic AI
text:
1.1 Course Schedule
We will meet for three sessions to learn, build, and present our work.







Date
Topic




Week 3, Dec.¬†8 (14:00-16:00)
Project Kick-off & FundamentalsIntroduction to Agentic AI, tooling, and setting up our environment.


Week 4, Dec.¬†15 (14:00-16:00)
Hands-on DevelopmentBuilding a simple agent and exploring design patterns.


Week 15, Mar.¬†9 (14:00-16:00)
Project PresentationFinal presentations, project reviews, and reflections.

title: Agentic AI
text:
1.2 The Project: SQL Analyst Agent

1.2.1 Objective
As AI consultants to Global Bike Inc.¬†(GBI), the objective is to design and implement a Python-based generative AI solution that enables self-service analytics through an agent capable of generating SQL from natural language.
The implementation should use Python as the primary language. All components must be included in a GitHub repository.


1.2.2 The Challenge
GBI has a lot of data in their Microsoft SQL Server, but accessing it requires technical skills. Business users want to ask questions in plain English and get immediate answers.


1.2.3 The Solution
Build an AI agent that turns text questions from GBI into safe, correct SQL, executes the query on GBI‚Äôs Microsoft SQL Server, and automatically produces both a suitable visualization and a plain-language explanation. The user interface displays the generated SQL, a data table, the visualization, and the explanation.
The end-to-end interaction can follow, as an example, the following path:

User Input: A user poses a question by text.
Text-to-SQL: The text question is converted into a SQL statement.
Execution: The statement is executed against the SQL Server and the resulting dataset is routed to:
A visualization component that selects an appropriate chart based on the data shape.
An explanation component that generates a narrative grounded in the returned numbers.
Presentation: The interface then presents the generated SQL, a paginated data table, the selected visualization, and an explanatory summary.

Note: This flow is provided to illustrate the intended user experience; you may refine it as needed while preserving the core capability of safe text-to-SQL, execution, visualization, and explanation.

title: Agentic AI
text:
1.3 Deliverables
Deliverables include a GitHub repository containing:

All code (agents, guardrails, database connector, and UI).
Configuration and prompt templates.
Reproducible setup instructions using uv python package manager.
A short explanation (one page) describing the architecture, prompts, safety measures, and evaluation procedure.

title: Agentic AI
text:
1.4 Expected Business Impact
A single natural-language interface that:

Reduces analyst bottlenecks.
Shortens time-to-insight for sales.
Standardizes how data is queried, visualized, and explained across GBI.

title: Agentic AI
text:
1.5 Technologies

Python: The primary programming language.
Google Gemini: For the intelligence (LLM).
Gradio: To build the user interface.
Microsoft SQL Server: The database.
VS Code: The primary IDE.
GitHub: To store and share your code.
uv: For Python package management.

title: Agentic AI
text:
1.6 Getting Started
To be ready for our first session, please complete the steps in the Preparation chapter before class. This includes installing software and setting up your development environment.
We look forward to building the future of analytics with you!

title: 2¬† Accounts
text:
2.1 Google Account
To be ready for our first session, please ensure you have the following accounts.
You will need a Google account to access Google‚Äôs AI tools:

title: 2¬† Accounts
text: Create Google Account

title: 2¬† Accounts
text:
2.2 Google API Key
To use Google‚Äôs AI model Gemini, you need an API key.

Go to Google AI Studio
Click ‚ÄúCreate API key‚Äù (at the bottom left of the page).
Follow the instructions to create the API key.

We come back to this step in a later chapter.

title: 2¬† Accounts
text:
2.3 GitHub Account
You will need a GitHub account to access GitHub.






Use your KMITL e-mail address to create a GitHub account. If you already have an account, simply add your KMITL e-mail address to your account. This will allow you to apply for the GitHub Student Developer Pack.




Create GitHub Account
You may also sign up for the GitHub Student Developer Pack to get access to GitHub Pro for free and additional benefits like GitHub Copilot.

title: 3¬† Windows
text:
3.1 Basic requirements
If you are using Windows, follow these steps.
First, make sure your system is up to date.
Next, enable Developer Mode:

title: 3¬† Windows
text:
Open Settings > Windows Update.



Open Settings > Update & Security > For developers.
Toggle Developer Mode and accept the disclaimer.

title: 3¬† Windows
text:
3.2 Command-line basics
We use Git Bash as our terminal. Download the latest Git for Windows installer from git-scm.com and complete the setup (Git Bash is included). After installation, open Git Bash from the Start menu.






NoteWhy Git Bash?





Git Bash provides a Unix-like terminal experience on Windows, making it easier to follow along with commands that are commonly used in macOS and Linux environments.



Keep the terminal window open while you work through the chapters.

3.2.1 uv
We use uv, a Python package manager that is extremely fast. It replaces pip, poetry, and virtualenv.
To install uv, follow this guide

title: 3¬† Windows
text:
3.3 Server Tools
The Microsoft ODBC Driver for SQL Server enables native connectivity from Windows applications to Microsoft SQL Server and Azure SQL databases.
Follow the steps below to install the ODBC Driver (version 18) and command-line tools on your Windows machine:

Installation Instructions

For most users, the ‚ÄúDownload Microsoft ODBC Driver 18 for SQL Server (x64)‚Äù installer is the right choice.

title: 4¬† macOS
text:
4.1 Basic requirements
If you are using Mac, follow these steps.
First, make sure your system is up to date.
Open System Settings > General > Software Update.

title: 4¬† macOS
text:
4.2 Command-line basics
Launch Terminal (Spotlight search for ‚ÄúTerminal‚Äù).
Commands in this book assume the zsh shell, which is the default on modern macOS systems.
Keep the terminal window open while you work through the chapters.

title: 4¬† macOS
text:
4.3 Xcode
Apple‚Äôs Xcode command line tools are required to build and run some of the code.
Install Xcode command line tools:
xcode-select --install
If you get the following message, you can skip this step:
xcode-select: note: Command line tools are already installed. Use ‚ÄúSoftware Update‚Äù in System Settings or the softwareupdate command line interface to install updates

title: 4¬† macOS
text:
4.4 Package manager
Homebrew downloads applications, command line tools, and libraries with one command. You avoid manual downloads and it keeps everything organized.

4.4.1 Install Homebrew

Open Terminal and run the official installer:

/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"

Enter your password when prompted (you won‚Äôt see any characters while typing).
Press ENTER to continue
When the script finishes, follow the on-screen instructions to add Homebrew to your shell profile (this step is required for brew to be found).
Close the Terminal window.
Open a new Terminal, then verify the installation:

brew --version


4.4.2 Update Homebrew
If you already have Homebrew installed, make sure everything is up to date:
brew update
Use brew upgrade to actually update installed packages.
brew upgrade

title: 4¬† macOS
text:
4.5 uv
We use uv, a Python package manager that is extremely fast. It replaces pip, poetry, and virtualenv.
To install uv, follow this guide

title: 4¬† macOS
text:
4.6 Server Tools
We need to install some drivers for Microsoft SQL Server.

4.6.1 Install Server Tools
Open your Terminal and run:
brew tap microsoft/mssql-release https://github.com/Microsoft/homebrew-mssql-release
ACCEPT_EULA=Y brew install msodbcsql18 mssql-tools unixodbc

msodbcsql18 is the latest Microsoft ODBC Driver for SQL Server.
mssql-tools installs sqlcmd and bcp for command-line access.
unixodbc provides the shared ODBC libraries Python will load.







The ACCEPT_EULA=Y prefix lets the installer know you accept the Microsoft end-user license agreement. Without it the install stops halfway through.




Close and reopen Terminal.



4.6.2 Test the installation
Confirm that the ODBC driver registered correctly:
odbcinst -j
Look for lines referencing Driver Manager: unixODBC.
Your Mac is now ready to connect to SQL Server databases from VS Code and Python.


4.6.3 Troubleshooting
Some shells require an extra step to expose the SQL Server utilities. Add the following line to ~/.zshrc or ~/.bash_profile if sqlcmd is not found after reopening Terminal:
export PATH="/opt/homebrew/opt/msodbcsql18/bin:/opt/homebrew/opt/mssql-tools/bin:$PATH"
Intel Macs should use /usr/local/opt/ instead of /opt/homebrew/opt/.
Reload your shell:
source ~/.zshrc

title: 5¬† VS Code
text:
5.1 Install VS Code
Visual Studio Code acts as your code editor, terminal, and database explorer. This chapter covers the essential extensions and workspace settings for SQL Server work.
If you haven‚Äôt already, install Visual Studio Code:
Launch VS Code once to allow it to finish installing components.

title: 5¬† VS Code
text:
macOS: Download the from code.visualstudio.com and drag Visual Studio Code into Applications.
Windows: Download the installer and click through the setup, leaving the default options enabled (add to PATH, register the code command, etc.).

title: 5¬† VS Code
text:
5.2 Essential extensions
Open the Extensions view and install:

Python (ms-python.python) ‚Äì language support and linting.
SQL Server (mssql) (ms-mssql.mssql) ‚Äì database connections and query runner.
vscode-icons (vscode-icons-team.vscode-icons) ‚Äì file icons for better visual identification.

title: 5¬† VS Code
text:
5.3 Enable the code command

5.3.1 macOS Terminal

Launch VS Code, press Cmd+Shift+P, and run Shell Command: Install ‚Äòcode‚Äô command in PATH.
Close any open Terminal windows, then open a new one and run
code --version
to confirm the CLI is available.
From the folder you want to open, run
code .
to launch VS Code in that location.



5.3.2 Windows

From the folder you want to open, run this in Git Bash
code .
to launch VS Code in that location.
If the command is missing, add VS Code‚Äôs bin directory to your Git Bash PATH by appending the snippet below to ~/.bashrc (create the file if it doesn‚Äôt exist):
VS_CODE="/c/Users/$USERNAME/AppData/Local/Programs/Microsoft VS Code/bin"
if [ -d "$VS_CODE" ] && [[ ":$PATH:" != *":$VS_CODE:"* ]]; then
  PATH="$VS_CODE:$PATH"
fi
Reload Git Bash
source ~/.bashrc
Try again:
code .

title: 5¬† VS Code
text:
5.4 Integrated terminal tips

Open the integrated terminal in VS Code. On Windows, set Git Bash as the default shell so every VS Code terminal matches the rest of this guide.
Set your default terminal profile via Terminal > Configure Default Profile‚Ä¶ so that VS Code opens the same shell you used during installation.

title: 6¬† Server Connection
text:
6.1 VS Code extension
We can connect to SQL Server using the SQL Server extension in VS Code or via Python scripts. We will discuss both methods in this section.
Use the SQL Server extension in VS Code to connect, save, and reuse profiles for SQL Server or Azure SQL databases. The steps below walk through creating your first connection and include tips for common authentication modes.

title: 6¬† Server Connection
text:
6.1.1 Create a connection profile

In VS Code, open the SQL Server view (activity bar icon with the SQL badge).
Select Add Connection (‚ûï icon). The Connect to Database dialog matches the screenshot and uses the following fields:

Profile Name ‚Äì friendly label that shows up under SQL Server ‚ñ∂ Connections.
Connection Group ‚Äì optional folder for organizing profiles. Leave <Default>.
Input type

Use Parameters (default): exposes the individual fields listed below.

Server name ‚Äì Use the named instance provided by your instructor.
Trust server certificate ‚Äì enable this field.
Authentication type ‚Äì select SQL Login
User name / Password ‚Äì enter the credentials provided by your instructor.
Save Password ‚Äì stores credentials securely in your OS keychain.
Database name ‚Äì enter the name provided by your instructor..
Encrypt ‚Äì pick Optional.
Advanced ‚Äì not necessary for this connection.

After filling the required fields (marked with *), click Connect. When prompted, save the profile. Saving makes it appear in the SQL Server panel so you can double-click it later; declining runs a one-off connection only.



6.1.2 Verify the connection
Next, verify the connection:

In your VS Code Extensions, open the SQL Server view if not already visible.
In the CONNECTIONS window, move your mouse to the name of your database, right-click and choose New Query.
Type a simple check such as:

SELECT TOP (3)
ID_Product,
Material_Description,
Product_Category,
Transfer_Price_EUR
FROM dbo.Dim_Product
ORDER BY ID_Product;

Press F5 or click the Run symbol (‚ñ∂Ô∏è) in the editor toolbar (at the top right of the script).
The Results grid should return the products ordered by ID_Product. If VS Code prompts again for credentials, re-enter them and retry.
If you encounter connection issues, double-check the server name, authentication type, and credentials. Review any error messages for clues.

title: 6¬† Server Connection
text:
6.2 Python Server Connection
You can also connect to SQL Server from Python using SQLAlchemy.
To make the process smoother, all necessary files are already available in a GitHub repository. Follow the instructions to clone it and set up your environment:
GitHub Repository: mssql-example

title: 7¬† Introduction
text:
In this section, we will explore the concept of Agentic AI, which refers to artificial intelligence systems capable of autonomous decision-making and actions.
Please take a moment to complete the following survey before we begin:

Link to anonymous survey


Introduction to Agentic AI, tooling, and setting up our environment:






üìÑ Introduction to AI Agents

title: 8¬† Google ADK
text:
The Google Agent Development Kit (ADK) is a framework designed to facilitate the creation, deployment, and management of AI agents.
It provides tools and libraries that help developers build intelligent agents capable of performing complex tasks autonomously.
Get started with Google‚Äôs Agent Development Kit (ADK) by exploring this starter repository:






üíª First Agent Tutorial

title: 9¬† Context Engineering
text:
9.1 What is Context Engineering?
Context engineering is a crucial aspect of building effective AI agents. It involves the strategies and techniques used to provide relevant information to the agent, enabling it to make informed decisions and perform tasks efficiently.
Proper context engineering ensures that the agent has access to the necessary data, knowledge, and situational awareness required for optimal performance.
Recommended reading:
Rajasekaran, P., Dixon, E., Ryan, C., & Hadfield, J. (2025). Effective context engineering for AI agents. Anthropic.

title: 9¬† Context Engineering
text: üìÑ Introduction to context engineering

text:
9.2 Context Construction
System Prompt & Prompt Engineering:






üìÑ Context Construction - Prompt Engineering
